Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: The construction would also have an impact on other Black residents in the community, who believe it would affect their quality of life.
Other residents told Capital B they feared potential damage to their homes from the train.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “We’re determined to keep fighting against this attempt to take our ancestral land from us.”
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: one of the heirs of 600 acres

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “We want to keep our property whole, so we can pass it down to our children and they can continue to build generational wealth,”
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: one of the heirs of 600 acres

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “As Black people, ownership of land and property is more valuable than a dollar amount because it allows a certain type of economic freedom that we are often deprived of,”
“I don’t know what is ‘just’ about replacing that economic liberty with a dollar amount that will not increase in value.”
“Georgia law does not permit a private company to take land through eminent domain unless the land will be put to a public use,”
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: senior attorney for Institute for Justice

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “Building a rail spur that will only be used by a few private companies, and not the public at large, is not a public use. We look forward to making it clear to the court that the [Public Service Commission] made an error in considering Sandersville’s land grab as a public use.”
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: senior attorney for Institute for Justice

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “The reality is if you’ve ever lived near a train, or you’ve ever ridden on a train or been near a train, it’s not the same as trucks driving by,”
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: senior staff attorney with the Southern Poverty Law Center’s Economic Justice Project
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: who represents the No Railroad In Our Community Coalition

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “Even if the train is not going through your property, the fact that a train is near your property — all of the noise pollution, the vibrations of a train … all of that affects your property value, your peace of mind and your home.”
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: senior staff attorney with the Southern Poverty Law Center’s Economic Justice Project
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: who represents the No Railroad In Our Community Coalition

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “I truly hate to have to say this, but if David v. Goliath had been decided by the GA Public Service Commission, they’d have confiscated David’s slingshot and handed it to the Philistines,”
“The proposed condemnation … serves a legitimate public purpose and is necessary for the proper accommodation of the business,”
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: hearing officer with the Georgia Public Service Commission

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “The petition of Sandersville Railroad, as amended, is granted.”
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: hearing officer with the Georgia Public Service Commission

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: The railroad project involves constructing a 4.5-mile rail spur to connect the Hanson Quarry, a rock mine owned by Heidelberg Materials, to a main train line along a nearby highway.

Benjamin Tarbutton III, the owner of Sandersville Railroad, has contended this development is expected to create 20 temporary construction jobs, a dozen permanent jobs with an average salary and benefits package of $90,000, and generate over $1.5 million annually for Hancock County.
The property owners are represented by the nonprofit Institute for Justice, a public interest law firm.
